translated: Jātaka🔽The Collection of Birth Stories (Jātakas)
The Chapter of the Mango
The Phandana Jātaka
“A man with an axe in his hand,
you stand there seeking the forest;
When asked, good man, tell me,
what tree do you wish to cut down?”
“You wander through the forests,
the even and the uneven;
When asked, good man, tell me,
what tree do you want for a strong axle?”
“It’s not a sāla, nor a khadira,
nor an assakaṇṇa, let alone a dhavo;
The tree called phandana,
that wood is strong for an axle.”
“What are its leaves like,
and what is its trunk like?
When asked, good man, tell me,
so that we may know the phandana.”
“Its branches hang down,
bowing but not breaking;
That tree is called phandana,

analyzed: yassa mūle aham ṭhitaḥ  arānam cakkanābhīna
translated: at the foot of which I stand.🔽For the spokes, the hub,
and the axle of the chariot,
all of that can be made from it,
this will be the phandana.”
“Thus the phandana tree,
spoke thus for a while;
I too have a statement,
Listen to me, Bhāradvāja.
From the stump of the tree,🔽the arrow shot forth with force,
and struck the wheel-rim with its tip;
thus it became even more firmly fixed.

analyzed: iti  veram appesi tāvade  jātānañca ajātāna
translated: Thus the trembling tree🔽sent forth the arrow,🔽and the arrow brought suffering

analyzed: issānam dukkham āvahi  icca ivam phandanaḥ
translated: to the born and the unborn.🔽Thus the phandana sent forth the arrow,
and the arrow struck the phandana;
quarreling with each other,
they destroyed each other.
So it is with people,
wherever quarrels arise;
they dance the peacock dance,
like those phandanas and arrows.
I tell you this for your welfare,
you who have gathered here;
Be friendly, do not quarrel,
do not be like phandanas and arrows.

analyzed: sāmaggim eva sikkhetha  buddhā iha itam pasasita
translated: One should train in unity,🔽this is praised by the Buddha;
One who delights in unity, who is firm in the Dhamma,
is not destroyed by misfortune.”
The Phandana Jātaka is the second.
